pageProps.body:
Homogeneous Equations

Theorem. Any homogeneous linear ODE with constant coefficients has solutions of the form emxe^{mx}emx (and all multiples of it).

Proof. The following section will present two derivations of the above statement:

Method 1 (discrete approximation).

Suppose we are given the differential equation ay′−by=0ay' - by = 0ay′−by=0 for some constants aaa, bbb. One method of approaching this equation is to divide it into discrete timesteps of length hhh, for some hhh; that is, to define a sequence y0,y1,y2,...y_0, y_1, y_2, ...y0​,y1​,y2​,... such that y0=y(0),y1=y(h),y2=y(2h)y_0 = y(0), y_1=y(h), y_2=y(2h)y0​=y(0),y1​=y(h),y2​=y(2h), and so on. As y′y'y′ is geometrically the slope of yyy, we can write the differential equation above as ayn+1−ynh−byn=0a\frac{y_{n+1}-y_n}{h} - by_n = 0ahyn+1​−yn​​−byn​=0, which yields

ayn+1−ynh=bynyn+1−yn=bhaynyn+1=bh+aayn\begin{aligned} a\frac{y_{n+1}-y_n}{h}&=by_n \\ y_{n+1}-y_n &= \frac{bh}{a}y_n \\ y_{n+1} &= \frac{bh + a}{a}y_n \end{aligned}ahyn+1​−yn​​yn+1​−yn​yn+1​​=byn​=abh​yn​=abh+a​yn​​

applying this formula recursively yields

yn=(1+bha)ny0y_n = (1 + \frac{bh}{a})^n y_0yn​=(1+abh​)ny0​

Now let hhh equal xn\frac{x}{n}nx​, such that yn=f(nxx)=f(x)y_n = f(\frac{nx}{x}) = f(x)yn​=f(xnx​)=f(x). As nnn approaches infinity, the discrete approximation becomes infinitely close to the actual solution of the DE, so

y=lim⁡n→∞(1+bxa1n)ny0=y0ebxay = \lim_{n\to \infty} (1+\frac{bx}{a}\frac{1}{n})^n y_0 = y_0 e^{\frac{bx}{a}}y=n→∞lim​(1+abx​n1​)ny0​=y0​eabx​

due to the exponential limit.

Method 2 (Series solution).

Let yyy be the Taylor series y=∑n=0∞anxny = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_n x^ny=∑n=0∞​an​xn, with y′=∑n=1∞nanxn−1y' = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} n a_n x^{n-1}y′=∑n=1∞​nan​xn−1. Again consider the DE ay′−by=0ay'-by=0ay′−by=0; substituting yyy into this equation yields

ay′−by=∑n=0∞a(n+1)an+1xn−∑n=0∞banxn=∑n=1∞(a(n+1)an+1−ban)xn=0\begin{aligned} ay' - by &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a(n+1) a_{n+1} x^{n} - \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} ba_n x^n \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (a(n+1)a_{n+1} - ba_n)x^n \\ &= 0 \end{aligned}ay′−by​=n=0∑∞​a(n+1)an+1​xn−n=0∑∞​ban​xn=n=1∑∞​(a(n+1)an+1​−ban​)xn=0​

(note that the n+1n+1n+1 term instead of nnn originates from the fact that the bounds on the series have been adjusted to 000 to ∞\infty∞, instead of 111 to ∞\infty∞).

This implies that every term in the infinite sum is 0, or a(n+1)an+1−ban=0a(n+1)a_{n+1} - ba_n = 0a(n+1)an+1​−ban​=0; therefore, we write recursively that an+1=ba(n+1)ana_{n+1} = \frac{b}{a(n+1)}a_nan+1​=a(n+1)b​an​. Using this formula yields the general term an=(ba)n1n!a0a_n = (\frac{b}{a})^n\frac{1}{n!} a_0an​=(ab​)nn!1​a0​. Thus y=a0∑n=0∞(bxa)n1n!y = a_0 \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\frac{bx}{a})^n \frac{1}{n!}y=a0​∑n=0∞​(abx​)nn!1​ which is once again the exponential function ebxae^{\frac{bx}{a}}eabx​.
